chords.name: Major
chords.historicalBlurb: The major triad is the most common chord in Western music, conveying a bright, stable quality. It has been the harmonic backbone of tonal music since the Baroque.

chords.name: Minor
chords.historicalBlurb: The minor triad sounds darker than major and has been associated with melancholy or introspection in classical and popular music.

chords.name: Diminished
chords.historicalBlurb: The diminished triad creates tension and is often used as a passing chord or for dramatic effect in jazz and classical music.

chords.name: Augmented
chords.historicalBlurb: The augmented triad has a distinctive, unresolved quality and appears in late Romantic and impressionist music.

scales.name: Major
scales.historicalBlurb: The major scale is the foundation of Western tonality. Its pattern of whole and half steps (W-W-H-W-W-W-H) has defined melody and harmony for centuries.

scales.name: Natural Minor
scales.historicalBlurb: The natural minor (Aeolian) scale is the relative minor of the major scale and is widely used in folk, rock, and classical music.

scales.name: Harmonic Minor
scales.historicalBlurb: The harmonic minor scale raises the seventh degree to create a stronger pull to the tonic, common in Baroque and classical harmony.

scales.name: Pentatonic Major
scales.historicalBlurb: The major pentatonic scale omits the fourth and seventh degrees. It appears in folk music worldwide and in blues and rock.

arpeggios.name: Major
arpeggios.historicalBlurb: The major arpeggio outlines the major triad across octaves and is fundamental to piano technique and improvisation.
